clinical_study.brief_title: Does Goal Elicitation Improve Patient Perceived Involvement
clinical_study.official_title: Does Goal Elicitation Improve Patient Perceived Involvement?

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if goal elicitation among orthopaedic patients improves their perceived involvement in care.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a RCT with 2 intervention arms. In the first arm, the control arm, patients will be asked to complete a short questionnaire after their visit, to elicit demographic information and perceived involvement in care. The second arm, the intervention arm, will be asked to list 2 goals for their visit and complete a short questionnaire after their visit, to elicit demographic information and perceived involvement in care.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients will be randomized into 1 of 2 study arms arm 1: control arm 2: intervention. We will use a random block generator to assign participants to their study arm.
study_design_info.masking_description: The care provider will not be informed as to which group their patient is in.

primary_outcome.description: PICS measures the following: doctor facilitation of patient involvement, level of information exchange, and patient participation in decision making. Scale: 0-13, higher score means higher perceived involvement.

arm_group.description: Patients in the control group will be asked to complete a demographics survey and assess their perceived involvement in care after their visit

Patients in the intervention group will be asked to list 2 goals for their visit. They will also be asked to complete a demographics survey and access their perceived involvement in care after their visit.

intervention.description: Patients will be asked to list 2 goals for their visit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- New patients visiting the orthopaedic service
- English fluency and literacy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Returning patients
- Children
- Non-English speaking patients

patient_data.ipd_description: IPD will not be shared for this study.
